raw_text:
India's Deccan seals $1.8bn deal
 
 Air Deccan has ordered 30 Airbus A320 planes in a $1.8bn (£931m) deal as India's first low-cost airline expands in the fast-growing domestic market.
 
 Air Deccan was set up last year and wants to lure travellers away from the railway network and pricier rivals. The potential of the Indian market has attracted attention at home and abroad. Beer magnate Vijay Mallya recently set up Kingfisher Airlines, while UK entrepreneur Richard Branson has said he is keen to start a local operation.
 
 The country has a population of more than a billion people and many observers feel that it is underserved by airlines. Recently however, the booming economy has boosted personal spending power and helped swell the middle classes and the corporate sector. India's government has given its backing to cheaper and more accessible air travel. "The days of flying being a symbol of only maharajas or the rich are over," the minister for civil aviation Praful Patel said earlier. Infrastructure is being built to handle the expected increase in demand and on Tuesday, Agence France Presse reported that a group led by Germany's Siemens won the contract to build a private airport near Bangalore. India's airports authority and the state government will own 13% each of the finished transport hub. For its part, Air Deccan, set up by army officer and silk farmer Gorur Gopinath, plans to increase its fleet to 60 aircraft within five years. To help finance the expansion the company may sell a 25% stake to an investor for about $50m. When it was set up the firm offered tickets that were 50% cheaper than other Indian airlines. It said it was basing its business model on European firms such as Ireland's Ryanair.
llama3.2:1b: Air Deccan has ordered 30 Airbus A320 planes worth $1.8 billion in a deal with India's Air Deccan to expand into the country's growing domestic market. The airline, set up last year by Indian businessman Gorur Gopinath, wants to attract travelers away from the railway network and pricier rivals like Kingfisher Airlines.
llama3.2:3b: Air Deccan has ordered 30 Airbus A320 planes in a $1.8 billion deal, India's first low-cost airline expansion. The company plans to lure travelers away from the railway network and pricier rivals with cheaper tickets. The Indian market is expected to boost personal spending power and swell the middle classes and corporate sector, leading to increased demand for air travel.
gemma2:2b: Air Deccan, India's first low-cost airline, has ordered 30 Airbus A320 planes for $1.8 billion. The company aims to compete with the railway system and pricier rivals in India's growing domestic market. With a large population and a burgeoning middle class, demand for affordable air travel is high.  The Indian government supports cheaper air travel and infrastructure projects are underway to accommodate increasing passenger numbers. Air Deccan plans to expand its fleet to 60 aircraft within five years and may seek investment of $50 million. The company's business model draws inspiration from European low-cost airlines like Ryanair.
qwen2.5:0.5b: India’s Air Deccan, a low-cost airline, has signed an agreement worth $1.8 billion to purchase 30 Airbus A320 jets from China's Kingfisher Airlines and Indian Railways. The company aims to expand its presence in India by catering to the growing domestic market. With a population of over a billion people, the country is under-represented by airlines. However, with rising personal spending power and a booming economy, there is increasing interest in cheaper air travel options. Agence France Presse reported that a Siemens consortium won a contract for an airport near Bangalore. India's airports authority and state governments will own 13% of the new transport hub. The firm offers tickets that are 50% cheaper than other Indian airlines and bases its business model on European firms such as Ireland's Ryanair.
qwen2.5:1.5b: India's Deccan airline, backed by Vijay Mallya and Richard Branson, has ordered 30 Airbus A320 planes from Air Deccan for a $1.8bn deal to expand in the fast-growing domestic market. The project aims to appeal to middle-class travelers away from railway networks and pricier rivals, benefiting from India's growing economy and government support for cheaper air travel.
qwen2.5:3b: India's Deccan orders 30 Airbus A320 planes in $1.8bn deal, expanding in domestic market aimed at railway and pricier rivals. Air India's growth driven by large population, booming economy boosting personal spending and middle classes. Government supports affordable travel, investing in infrastructure like a new airport near Bangalore. Deccan plans to increase its fleet to 60 aircraft within five years, potentially selling 25% stake for $50m.
opencoder:1.5b:
India’s Deccan Seals $1.8bn Deal

Air Deccan has ordered 30 Airbus A320 planes in a $1.8bn (£931m) deal as India’s first low-cost airline expands in the fast-growing domestic market.

Air Deccan was set up last year and aims to lure travellers away from the railway network and pricier rivals. The potential of the Indian market has attracted attention at home and abroad, with beer magnates like Vijay Mallya and UK entrepreneurs Richard Branson keen on starting a local operation.

India's population is more than a billion and many observers find it underserved by airlines. However, recently, the booming economy has helped boost personal spending power and strengthened the middle classes and corporate sector. India’s government supports cheaper and more accessible air travel, and the country’s chief minister praised its backing to cheaper and efficient air travel.

India's airports authority and the state government own 13% of the transport hub. For its part, Air Deccan plans to increase its fleet to 60 aircraft within five years. To finance the expansion, it may sell a 25% stake to an investor for about $50m. The company also offers tickets priced 50% cheaper than other Indian airlines.

It bases its business model on European firms such as Ireland's Ryanair.
smollm:1.7b: India's Deccan seals a $1.8bn deal for Air Deccan, an airline aiming to lure travellers away from the railway network and pricier rivals. The potential of India's domestic market has attracted attention at home and abroad. Beer magnate Vijay Mallya recently set up Kingfisher Airlines, while UK entrepreneur Richard Branson is keen to start a local operation.

Air Deccan will use these planes to attract more passengers away from the railway network and expensive rivals. With a population of over a billion people, India has a thriving low-cost air travel market, but there have been concerns that it is underserved by airlines. Last year, Kingfisher Airlines was launched by British entrepreneur Richard Branson with an initial investment of $10m. UK-based airline company Flyadeco is also considering its options in India. The growth in spending power has led to increased demand for cheaper and more accessible air travel. The government's recent announcement that it will provide financial support for this expansion has boosted the market for low-cost airlines.

The government supports affordable air travel, as declared by Civil Aviation Minister Praful Patel, who noted that flying is no longer exclusive to the wealthy. To accommodate increased demand, infrastructure improvements are underway, including a private airport near Bangalore, owned equally by India's airports authority and state government. The airline models itself after European budget carriers like Ryanair, offering tickets half the price of competitors when it launched.
